Award.AwardTitle: NSF Student Travel Support for the 5th Career Workshop for Women and Minorities in Computer Architecture

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
The award supports travel grants for students to attend 5th Career Workshop for Women and Minorities in Computer Architecture (CWWMCA-2019) to be held in Columbus, OH, USA, in conjunction with the 52nd Annual IEEE/ACM International Symposium on Microarchitecture (MICRO). The Workshop for Women and Minorities in Computer Architecture provides a forum for sharing advanced academic and industrial research work focused on computer architecture and career development advice for women and minorities in academia, industrial and government labs.

The workshop will cover a wide range of topics with leading experts in the filed attending MICRO as keynote speakers, invited talks and panel focused on career development for women and other minorities in the field of computer architecture. Students attending this event will be exposed to the latest developments in the field, as well as benefit from personal interactions in a small-group setting with leading researchers from the domain.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Goal:

This fund was to support the student travel grant of CWWMCA 2019 workshop, which was collocated with MICRO 2019 at Columbus, Ohio, USA on Oct. 13th 2019. CWWMCA 2019 brought women and other under-represented minorities together to discuss therecruitment, retention, and progression of women and minorities in the research field of computer architecture.This workshop helped the students and researchers from the minority groups in three ways: (i) itprovided networking opportunity to socialize and form a sense of community, (ii) it provided mentoring andcareer advice from role models in the community to help them become successful in the future, and (iii) itserved as a platform for showcasing research to enhance their technical and presentation skill. We believethat this workshop offered a great platform for mentoring, networking, and promoting research for studentsand researchers.

 

Activities:

The workshop included keynotes and invited talks from well known researchers from academiaand industry, a student poster session and short presentations, a special session on the ways to form thiscommunity beyond the workshop and mental health in graduate school, a panel discussion on dealing withadversity as a minority and ways to survive graduate school in difficult moments, and a speed mentoringsession for the students. The detailed program can be found here [1]. Here is the list of speakers: Dr.Radha Ratnaparkhi (IBM Research), Prof. Mengjia Yan (MIT), Prof. Jun Yang (University of Pittsburgh),Prof. Y. Sophia Shao (University of California Berkeley), Prof. Reetuparna Das (University of Michigan),Prof. Vijay Janapa Reddi (Harvard University), Prof. Tamara Silbergleit Lehman (University of ColoradoBoulder), and Ms. Akshitha Sriraman (Ph.D. Candidate at the University of Michigan). The workshop had 34 main participants and a total of around 40-50 attendees. A total of 20 US resident students/researchers travel cost was reimbursed with this fund and 7 more students/researchers were supported by another fund from sigMICRO.

 

Broader Impact:

This workshop had direct impact on the participation of women and minorities in the field of computerarchitecture in two directions. First, both CWWMCA and the main MICRO conference were strengthenedas a result of the greater and more diverse attendance that this travel support had enabled. Second,those students receiving travel support personally benefited from the opportunity to engage in the technical,professional and social exchanges that CWWMCA fostered. We believe that these benefits will result intobroader impact on the whole community in two ways. First, we anticipate that the research results presentedat the workshop, as well as the emphasis on interaction between academic researchers and industrialdesigners, will be carried back by attendees to their home institutions, resulting in heightened awarenessand interests in science and technology, especially in computer architecture. Second, with the widespreadadvertising, especially aimed at the under-represented minorities, the award will encourage and facilitatediversity at this top-tier computer architecture conference.
